column3: @dongcarl can you rebase now that #22075 is merged.
Pushed d90ca1e8ffc0ede1da7f47cb2da864e2d29fddb0...4cc35daed557f38b080360a89036b2e97a6f78c2\n- Rebased after merge of #22075 \n- Added section in OP about signing on another computer

Concept ACK - Haven't really looked at the changes, but I ran though this and tried signing on a separate machine, which is my usual workflow. Guix sigs for 4cc35daed557f38b080360a89036b2e97a6f78c2 here: https://github.com/bitcoin-core/guix.sigs/pull/23.

Is this still a draft?

If you do a build and attest with some hosts, and then another build and attest with more hosts, the second attest will not update either of the `.SHA256SUMS` file. I think it should because there are some cases where a builder may build some of the hosts at a different time, e.g. if they acquire the macOS SDK after building and attesting.

Otherwise I like the chan
Concept ACK, changes sound great to me. Will test.\n
ACK 4cc35daed557f38b080360a89036b2e97a6f78c2\n\nReviewed code and did a build, attest, and verify to test.

Pushed 4cc35daed5..e2c40a4ed5

Updated to address the possible user flow @achow101 mentioned here: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/22182#issuecomment-859784891

Specifically: before using an existing `noncodesigned.SHA256SUMS` file, we will check if it is up-to-date (if it exactly the same as merging all the noncodesigned `SHA256SUMS.part`s). If it is, it will be used, otherwise, w
ping @Emzy @hebasto as you have both previously tested Guix  building.

Not related to this PR, so for future follow ups:
in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/6bc1eca01b2f88e081e71b783b3d45287700f8a5/contrib/guix/guix-attest#L21

`xargs` and `find` are not used in this script. But `diff` and `sort` are missed.
Ran through building and using `NO_SIGN` again and produced [new signatures for e2c40a4ed5272d72fea997bd936fba28bb753226](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/guix.sigs/pull/25) which match @hebasto.
tested ACK\nRun through guix building. Signing device was plugged intro the build machine, so only one signature improved the usability. \n
